values.comments:
Networked Life has already been taught as CIS 112 and serves as an introductory
flagship course for the MKSE program, designed to introduce undergraduates to a tightly
woven mixture of topics in computer science, economics, game theory, and network
science, all in the context of the modern technology industry.
Engineering students lamented that the course did not cover more mathematics
and theory behind the concepts. Students believed that many of the class topics could
have been better explained in terms of quantitative descriptions, but instead were
conveyed through “somewhat oversimplified non-quantitative terms.” The material of
the course interested many students, and the interactive experiments and demos were a
favorite of many.
Professor Kearns was seen as a great professor, but some students wished that he
kept his notes and class readings more organized and gave more incentive for students to
go to class.
The class relied on two homework assignments, a midterm, and a final to produce
a final grade for the class, which some students saw as being unfair. The tests were much
harder than the homework and class lectures led students to believe, and the grading of
the course disappointed many students.
